head.title: Putting Pay for Performance to the Test

hedline.hl1: Putting Pay for Performance to the Test

block.p: At some companies, changes in chief executives' pay roughly corresponded with changes in their shareholders' total return last year. Several exceptions were in favor of shareholders, while other outliers favored C.E.O.'s.
Entergy J. Wayne Leonard $15.5 million His pay includes $7.8 million in stock, which can be cashed out in only three years.
General Electric Jeffrey R. Immelt $15.2 million Mr. Immelt's 2006 pay includes a $6.3 million stock award that is subject to cash flow and investor return over 5 years.
Citigroup Charles O. Prince III $24.9 million Among Wall Street chiefs, the embattled Citigroup boss received the lowest annual pay package.
Merrill Lynch E. Stanley O'Neal $46.4 million A change-in-control at Merrill could land Mr. O'Neal a $251 million exit package.
Berkshire Hathaway Warren E. Buffett $214,250 In 2006, Mr. Buffett received $100,000 in base pay. Of course, he holds $40.7 billion in Berkshire shares.
Apple Steven P. Jobs $1.00 Mr. Jobs received only $1 in total compensation. But his year-end holdings of Apple stock exceeded $414 million.
AT&T Edward E. Whitacre Jr. $31.5 million Mr. Whitacre can also expect about $74 million in deferred pay and $84 million in pension in retirement.
Occidental Petroleum Ray R. Irani $52.1 million Even with a pay cut, Mr. Irani was second on the 2006 list; he also cashed out $270 million stock option profits.
Washington Mutual Kerry K. Killinger $18.1 million Mr. Killinger's pay fell by nearly 30% while shareholders enjoyed a 9.3% return in 2006.
Amgen Kevin W. Sharer $18.6 million Mr. Sharer's pay rose about 11% in 2006. Amgen's stock dropped 13.4% drop last year.
Texas Instruments Richard K. Templeton $12.4 million In 2006 less than 20% of his pay was tied to concrete performance targets.
Toll Brothers Robert I. Toll $23.4 million Mr. Toll received a $17.5 million bonus last year, about 2.5 percent of profits, as shares fell 21.7%.
Motorola Edward J. Zander $12.7 million Mr. Zander's pay in 2006 included $350,999 for personal use of corporate aircraft.
Goldman Sachs Group Lloyd C. Blankfein $54.3 million Mr. Blankfein was the highest paid chief on Wall Street and off.
Graph tracks 2006 shareholder total return* and change in chief executive's compensation from previous year for selected companies.
Off the Charts A look at some of the outliers shows examples of extreme growth in pay.
Boston Scientific Pay Increase: +1,410%
Synnex: +232%
Kohl's: +229%
Seagate Technology: +146%
Pepco: +106%
Solectron: +174%
*For the company's fiscal year
(Tommy McCall for The New York Times)
(Source by Equilar, Inc.)
